title: Communicating SA Effectively
content: SA communication should be clear, concise, and complete: what you see, what it means, what you expect. Don't bury critical information in long explanations. Use a format: 'I observe X, I interpret it as Y, I expect Z.' Make it easy for teammates to build their SA from your report.

mcq.question: Which statement best communicates SA to your team?

options.B: Pressure is 285 PSI, trending up 3 PSI per minute, approaching our 300 PSI limit in about 5 minutes
options.C: We might have a pressure issue soon

mcq.explanation: This provides perception (285 PSI), comprehension (trending up, approaching limit), and projection (5 minutes). The team can immediately build shared SA from this complete statement.

openQuestions: How would you verbalize your current SA in 15 seconds?
What SA information does your team most need from you?
